physDesc.p: The letter consists of six sheets of paper with typing on both sides. At the top of each sheet (every other page) is a page number. There are some places where edits have been added in pencil.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter came yesterday and was a perfect delight to get. It makes me very happy to feel the staunch friendship which you and Hilda have for me; and you must realize by this time how absolutely it is returned. I almost wept at the idea of your doing a portrait of me for the July number. I shall appreciate it very much. I am awfully glad that you have taken Hilda down to the country. Don’t let her do too much. So many women go to pieces because they get up too soon. I wish to Goodness I could see you. A year ago to-day I sailed, and now that the time comes around, I cannot bear to think that I am going to lose my summer with you. I am only hoping this terrible war will be over, and I can surely go another year; and I am still hoping that you and Hilda will take a trip over to America and see things with your own eyes.

You do not answer a thing about whether there is any possibility of your coming and trying the translating job. Mr. Engel, who is the one that suggested it and who is in the Boston Music Company, asked me the other day whether I had heard anything definite from you. I think, if you chose to come and take it, you could hold it as long as you pleased and make a good income out of it. But, then, as you may, you are making a little hold in London with “The Egoist,” and I do not know what to advise. Only tell me something to reply to them.

I have the best news to give you with regard to the Anthology. It seems to be attracting a lot of notice. Ferris Greenslet told me to-day that “Town and Country,” in a review of another book, had said that three important things had happened this year: the European war, “The New Republic,” and Imagist Poetry. And he says the sale is going on steadily at the rate of about five copies a day. That is very good for this kind of a book, I think, and I am delighted to think that in clinging to me so splendidly as you have done, you have not lost in the selling line anyway.

Harriet has written Greenslet a letter, complaining that we did not mention “Poetry” in our preface, and I have sent her the enclosed letter in answer. I do believe we shall have to mention “Poetry” in the preface of the next number.

And by the way, we ought to be getting that next number together, or rather thinking about it. We ought to have the thing all made up by December or January. I advised waiting as long as possible before collecting our things, so that we can all have more to choose from, and I think the best way would be for you to gather in the English things and send them to me, and I will gather Fletcher’s and mine and send them to you; and then if you object to any of mine, or I object to any of yours, we can try again on the disputed poems. Of course, all that will take some little time so I think it would be well for us to begin, and try to get our first batches over to each other by the first of December. Of course, if you decide to come over here, it will be much easier for us, and we can do it all by word of mouth as we did last year.

I am not at all surprised at what you tell me about Hueffer. He has disliked me from the first. I believe him to be a perfectly unreliable person and, of course, I knew his feeling toward me when he did not review me for the “Outlook.” In fact, I have really always known it. It won’t make any difference; we have got beyond needing his help. But the way you stuck to our agreement through thick and thin is magnificent, and I am awfully grateful to you.
I wish Sadler would send me a copy of his novel. Greenslet says it is no good, and that they refused to publish it over here; but, of course, this is in confidence.

It is fine about the British Weekly, and good about Kournos. There is a little poetry magazine here called “The Poetry Journal.” It has been very poor, but they have just got themselves re-endowed and have started again. What makes me doubt about it is that Miss Blanch Shumaker Wagestaffs [sic] (you remember you had a book of hers to review last year) is one of the editors and the chief backer, I believe. But they have asked Fletcher and me to send them some things, and we have each done it; and if you care to send them any, I think they would be delighted to receive them. The address is: Studio Book Shop, 68 Pemberton Sq., Boston. Or you can do it through me, if you had rather. Brown, who has the Studio Book Shop and is the man who wrote Miss Weaver subscribing for several copies of “The Egoist” to carry in stock, is interested in “The Poetry Journal.” He is also making a collection of autograph copies of the books of all the poets he can get hold of, and he has written to ask me for your address and that of various other people, and I have given it to him.

As for the Academy, thank you for taking such a lot of trouble to find out if it was any good. I do not believe in taking hold of a broken-down magazine and trying to bring it up, anyway. A new thing, even a little thing, would be better than that. If you were over here, and could be the editor, it might be worth while to see what money we could raise to get up a small paper, but I made a lot of inquiries here, and everybody tells me that, unless you include politics and sociology, there is no chance of any paper living. I thought that May Sinclair’s article was excellent, and I shall certainly send round those copies as soon as I get them. They have not come yet.
I telephoned in to Ferris as soon as I got your letter about the de Régnier stories. He tells me he has written you direct, so I won’t mix up with that.

I think your idea of printing poetry of the younger Frenchmen is most excellent. Harriet ought to want some, but you know what she is like. If you want to send me some and have me send them on to her, I will; but I should think you could communicate with her as well as I. I certainly have no more pull with her than you have.

There is not the slightest doubt that we are getting on and getting on excellently. The head of the English Department asked me to come out to Wellesley, one of our largest women’s colleges, and give them a talk on “The New Manner in Modern Poetry.” I tried to be very eclectic and took all the poets who were any good, and brought Imagism in at the end. I read a couple of poems each of yours and Hilda’s, and they were immensely li`ked. I hear the very nicest accounts from Yale. Apparently some members of the English department are interested. I have a poem in the “Yale Review” this month. It is a quarterly, and is supposed to be the best magazine in the country. And they have written and asked me to send another, and Miss Hart has asked me to give another talk at Wellesley next year. Also I am to talk before the New York Poetry Society upon Imagism and vers libre in November. They are getting up a little poetry club here, consisting of nothing but poets, to meet once a month, and chat and rub up against each other. Several people came and asked me to be president, so as to jolt it out of the academic hole in which these things usually flounder. I hate that kind of thing, but it seemed to me that it might be a means of inoculating people, so I took the job. Fletcher is a member because, although he has gone out to his family now, he expects to be back next Autumn. So you see, things are really walking along.

My book on “Six French Poets,” being my lectures done over, is being brought out by Macmillan this Autumn. They are doing it very nicely, with portraits of each author and complete bibliographies. The only trouble is that they insist upon my translating all the poems I quote in an appendix. Of course, I am making prose translations; but as there are about 150 of them, it is a chore. Still, I think about the book ought to do us all good, because it will show that we are serious and sensible people, and not mere freaks. I am going to mention Flint and his admirable work for French poetry in the preface, he was so kind to me last year in helping me to books, etc. His letter was a little patronizing, but I forgive him.

I am sending you Braithwaite’s answer to Conrad Aiken’s article in “The New Republic.” I do not think it is half bad. Braithwaite brings out an Anthology of magazine verse every Autumn. It has been pretty rotten up to date, but it has an immense circulation, and now that he has jumped heart and soul into our cause, he says he is going to make a feature of Imagist poetry and write a lot out it in his preface.
Don’t worry a bit about our quarrelling. We have been through a lot and have stuck like glue, and if we continue to stand shoulder to shoulder, I believe we shall get ahead splendidly.
body.closer: Ever so much love to you both,

div.note: Aldington's November 25, 1914 letter to Lowell described his own falling out with Ford Madox Hueffer and warned that "his sentiments for you are not quite as noble as he professes."
Michael Sadleir's novel Hyssop: A Novel was published by Constable, 1915, and contrary to Ferris Greenslet's comment to Lowell, an American edition came out the following year through Brentano.

The Academy and Literature, formerly The Academy (1869-1902) was a British cultural magazine. It changed hands and titles many times during its run, and had three editors in 1915 alone, before closing.The publication was kept alive as a dummy magazine so that it could maintain rights to the name and was eventually absorbed into Lord Alfred Douglas's magazine Plain English in 1920 (Douglas had been editor between 1907-1910.
Sophie Chantal Hart (1868-1948) was an American educator. A professor of composition at Wellesley College, she served as Head of the English Department from 1906-1936.
Lowell was the first president of the New England Poetry Club, which started in May, 1915.
